Posts.Content: Agreed. Very interesting. This was certainly the case for me as the Gleason score was upgraded post surgery and cancer was found in both lobes rather than only the one that was revealed in the biopsy. I wavered big time on the surgery, but I now feel like it was the right decision for me.

Posts.Content: The whole prostate cancer experience is a wall of confusion anyway with so many competing ideas and opinions. My feeling is that an article like this may convince some men that there is no need to get screened at all.
Posts.Signature: Age 50, 47 at DX PSA 4.2 on 01/14/2016 Open Surgery on 09/14/2016 Stage pT2c pNO MO, G7 (3+4) Most recent PSA <0.1
Posts.Title: UK study of PC screening

Posts.Content: Wanted to update you guys. Had RRP on Sep 14 and doing well. Post-op pathology indicated that tumor was confined to prostate, but it was upgraded to 3+4=7 and it was bilateral. I really wavered on surgery, but I'm glad it's gone. Catheter was tough on a big baby like me, but I'm doing very well with continence...far beyond my best expectations. The other department is Rip Van Winkle, unfortunately. Ironically, I have a strong desire to go after my wife of 20 years as if I were a teenager. I know it's (very) early, but I hope old Rip starts to wake up soon. I am fortunate to have a good support group around me, my workplace has been great, and I have been very pleased with my urologist and his staff. Real pros. I thank all of you vets here on this site also. I haven't posted a lot since discovering this forum, but I've read and learned a lot. God bless.

Posts.Title: Pre day jitters

Posts.Content: Mr. Baseball: Best wishes for a smooth procedure and recovery. Best advice that I got was from one of the sages here, Jim: Get a good recliner. I had a difficult time trying to sleep in the bed with the catheter, so the recliner helped me considerably. I didn't walk much with that infernal catheter, but once removed I pretty quickly got up to 6 miles a day. Those early morning walks were important for my mental health and, after the whole whirlwind ordeal, just to be outside in nature was a real blessing.
Posts.Signature: Age 50, 47 at DX PSA 4.2 on 01/14/2016 Open Surgery on 09/14/2016 Stage pT2c pNO MO, G7 (3+4) Most recent PSA <0.1

Posts.Title: RP Exactly One Week From Today - Any Last Minute Advice?

Posts.Content: Greetings and best wishes to everyone. Just had my 1 year (14 mos) follow-up after having open RP and happy to report that I am still <0.1. In addition, Mr. Happy is beginning to cooperate with me, which is a relief. However, the little guy has a noticeable bend now (maybe 20Â°). I know this can sometimes be a side effect of injections, but (so far) I’ve only used the little pill. My question is, has anyone experienced this and does it eventually get better? Thanks, Drbbt
Posts.Signature: Age 50, 47 at DX PSA 4.2 on 01/14/2016 Open Surgery on 09/14/2016 Stage pT2c pNO MO, G7 (3+4) Most recent PSA <0.1
Posts.Title: Peyronies

Posts.Content: Denis: I enjoy your writing and you often capture my feelings in a way that I have difficulty expressing. I am dealing with some of the adverse side effects right now and have my 2 year follow-up in a few days. I have the bi-annual anxiety about the blood test and the what-if scenarios. The whole experience has been a revelation to me in many ways. I have thought more deeply about what is important in life than ever before and there has been a reshuffling of my priorities. Every day, even the most mundane, has taken on new significance. Your post was the first thing that I read this morning. Thanks for the reminder. -D
Posts.Signature: Age 50, 47 at DX PSA 4.2 on 01/14/2016 Open Surgery on 09/14/2016 Stage pT2c pNO MO, G7 (3+4) Most recent PSA <0.1
Posts.Title: I have cancer, cancer does not have me!

Posts.Content: Zen, I had mine read at JH back in July and I'm pretty sure the sum total was $250. I didn't process it through my insurance. My uro office handled the paperwork and shipping of original slides and Hopkins sent me the bill. Turns out that my local pathology reading and Hopkins drew the same conclusion. You might want to call them directly. Good luck. -Drbbt

Posts.Title: I have cancer, cancer does not have me!

Posts.Content: Hello everyone. I'd like to say that I am happy to be here, but I will say that I am happy that this forum is here. This is my first post, but I've been helped immensely by what I have found here already. I found out that I have PCa on July 22nd, just 4 days before my 48th birthday. I was not new to urology as I began having occasional bouts of prostatitis back in my early 30s. My PSA had fluctuated a bit over the past 5 years, but had never gone above 2.5 and had always settled back down. Couple of years ago it climbed to 2.6 and created some anxiety for me. We retested and it dropped to 1.7. For the next year, I forgot that I even had a prostate. Then it shot up to 4.2 (!!!) a year later. Based my history of chronic prostatitis and years of fluctuations, my doctor recommended a round of antibiotics and a retest. 2 months later it was down to 3.2. He told me to come back in four months, but it was basically the same at 3.1. He recommended the biopsy (which was slightly uncomfortably in one lobe, but hurt like a mug in the other!). Results revealed 3/12 cores positive (all Gleason 6) with up to 30% of volume in the three cores. No evidence of PIN. I took the news like a champ, but slowly unraveled over the next few days. My uro has done hundreds of open prostatectomies and recommended surgery, although he took a couple of hours to explain all of my options to me and did not push anything. He said that I had some time and that I should carefully weigh my options. I have done my research and talked to other doctors, but believe surgery is my best course of action. I have been fortunate to have never had surgery in my life and I have some apprehension, but I also have a young family and I want the best shot that I can get. I am leaning on God and my always supportive wife and I am very grateful to have found this forum.
Posts.Signature: Age 50, 47 at DX PSA 4.2 on 01/14/2016 Open Surgery on 09/14/2016 Stage pT2c pNO MO, G7 (3+4) Most recent PSA <0.1

Since I was only 47 at diagnosis, I know my young sons are at greater risk. I would like to see a follow up study on the participants of this trial at 5 and 10 years. In the meantime, we can hope. Thanks for sharing.

Posts.Title: Where in The World is Jim215?

Posts.Content: A PSA about PSA! Thanks for sharing Frank...I'm certain that there are men in your area who are now visiting their doctors because of this segment. I've known men over the years who don't know what their prostate is or what it does or that is even needs to be checked. Fortunately for me, A severe bout of prostatitis brought me to a urologist and I began to educate myself on the conditions of the prostate. Diagnosed in my 40s, I'm afraid of what might have happened if I never had prostatitis and waited until 55 (as some recommend) to get a PSA. The more you know...
Posts.Signature: Age 50, 47 at DX PSA 4.2 on 01/14/2016 Open Surgery on 09/14/2016 Stage pT2c pNO MO, G7 (3+4) Most recent PSA <0.1

Posts.Title: I went public with my diagnosis

Posts.Content: Another new guy here diagnosed in July. Had Open RP on 9/14 (mine was Gleason 7) and doing remarkably well here just 6 weeks later. I was bewildered after getting the news, but I followed the advice of the wise folks here to 1) get Dr. Walsh's book, 2) get a second opinion, and 3) have my pathology slides looked at by Dr. Epstein. I began to feel more in control as I gained more knowledge. Everyone here is supportive and, in my case, stumbling upon this forum was (and is) a godsend. I'm sure you're going to be fine. Please keep us updated.
Posts.Signature: Age 50, 47 at DX PSA 4.2 on 01/14/2016 Open Surgery on 09/14/2016 Stage pT2c pNO MO, G7 (3+4) Most recent PSA <0.1
Posts.Title: Worried about my prostate diagnosis

Posts.Content: First PSA after RP today and it was <0.1. Man, that's a great looking number! Seven weeks out of surgery and peeing with a very good stream when I have a full bladder. Sometimes, however, I have an urge to pee when I'm not full and the stream is weak with dribbles. I also seem to want to pee a lot, although it has lessened over the past couple of weeks. I was getting up to pee 6 times a night and now it's down to three. Has anyone had a similar experience? I see my uro in a couple of days, but it's good to know what others have experienced. Thanks!
Posts.Signature: Age 50, 47 at DX PSA 4.2 on 01/14/2016 Open Surgery on 09/14/2016 Stage pT2c pNO MO, G7 (3+4) Most recent PSA <0.1
Posts.Title: Urine stream after RP
